texts.shortText: Once thought to be a form of the widespread African hamadryas baboon Papio hamadryas, but now recognized as a separate species.

Adults dark brown with long, downward-sloping face. Limbs elongate and the front foot only about half as long as the back foot. Tail characteristically carried with the first third held upwards and the distal two-thirds drooping downwards. Male much larger and more robust that female with enlarged head, massive canine teeth and a mane of long hair on the back of the neck and shoulders. Female much lighter in build with smaller head and have obvious callosities on the rump. Juveniles black.
Males much larger than females and attaining a mass of up to 44 kg, while females only reach 21 kg. Body length up to 115 cm and tail an additional 45–84 cm.

Global: Widespread across southern Africa, from southern Angola and Zambia southwards to the Cape Peninsula.

Local/Regional: Essentially an inland species widespread across the region except in driest areas.

Mostly occur inland and live in fairly large troops across the region, except in the driest areas. Troops maintain territories across which they forage by day, sleeping at night on cliffs or in large trees, where they can escape predators. Included here because some troops in the Western Cape have taken to habitually foraging on the sea-shore.

Omnivorous, feeding mostly on fruits, leaves and invertebrates but also observed to hunt reptiles, birds and small mammals. Also frequently come into contact with humans and have learn to enter buildings or open car doors to take food and to even take items directly from humans.

Some troops on the cape Peninsula have learnt to supplement their diets by feeding on marine organisms during low tide. This food taken are protein rich ones, such as mussels and limpets, as well as the eggs of catsharks, which are often laid attached to seaweeds in intertidal pools and represent a particularly rich protein source. Marine foods only represent about 10% of the total diet even in these troops.

Puberty is reached at an age of 4–6 years depending on location. On reaching adulthood males usually disperse to other troops, but females remain with their natal group. Females have an estrous cycle of an average of 36 days and the stage of the cycle is indicated by the colour of the skin around the callosities and mating is usually with the dominant male. Gestation period is 6 months and a single offspring is born at any time of the year. The mother carries the young initially on her underside, but later on her back. Larger young may sit jockey-style on the mother’s back just in front of the tail. Lactation normally lasts at least 8 months.

Carlton, JT & Hodder, J (2003). Maritime mammals: terrestrial mammals as consumers in marine intertidal communities. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 256, 271-286.

Lewis, MC & O’Riain, MJ (2017). Foraging profile, activity budget and spatial ecology of exclusively natural-foraging chacma baboons (Papio ursinus) on the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. International Journal of Primatology, 38, 751-779.
